Posts.Content: Hi Can you describe the symptoms of breast lymphodema please? I had wle plus lymph clearance in Feb last year, followed by chemo then rads which finished at the end of Aug - it wasn't until early Dec that I noticed swelling in the affected breast. When I wake in the morning my breast is swollen on the underside with a slight orange peel texture to the skin and tender to touch however,  in the evening when I take off my bra, the symptoms are hardly noticeable. My BCnurse told me this is to be expected and all normal so soon after radiotherapy - I'm thinking it is the start of breast lymphodema and my bra is directing the lymphatic fluid into the right places but when not wearing one, it seems to be pooling into the underside of my breast - does this sound familiar? Loolyboo xxx
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi Can you describe the symptoms of breast lymphodema please? My BCnurse told me this is to be expected and all normal so soon after radiotherapy - I'm thinking it is the start of breast lymphodema and my bra is directing the lymphatic fluid into the right places but when not wearing one, it seems to be pooling into the underside of my breast - does this sound familiar? Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi Julia Thank you (:  I'm def going to take your advice on the kinesio taping, mentioned it to my oncologist and he thinks it's a good thing too but unfortunately not available anymore through my hospital - I will do some research for someone trained locally and go from there. I like the sound of the herbal oil, esp since it smells good too - on my shopping list! You know, I did my weekly grocery shop today and it wasn't until I put the bags in my car that I realised I hadn't thought once about cancer whilst shopping - made me smile (:  Time is certainly a great healer as they say, then to come home to the results of my mammogram .. I wish I had bought a bottle of something fizzy!  Love
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi A little update, so I had my first annual mammogram last week on the 17th Jan & it was very painful but over in seconds, radiographer was v kind (: I then went on to speak with my oncologist who agreed it appears I have slight edema to my breast and that the appearance was completely normal 5mths after radio. He advised how to massage towards the unaffected breast to enable the lymph fluid to flow easily via the motorway and not the a-roads (his words!) Today, I received the results from the mammogram and I'm pleased to say that I'm now a NEDY too, woooohoooo!  This time last year I could never imagine reaching this point but I've done it and you all can too! This forum has been an absolute godsend to me, a big thank you to everyone ((:

Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi Thank you for your replies -good news is that I'm feeling much better today, even managed 15 minutes on the running machine this morning which I couldn't have done last wk - definitely agree that exercise helps. I saw my oncologist yesterday & he reassured me that with herceptin being an antibody it will cause flu type aches & can be accumulative throughout the treatment... Oh well, only 9 more to go!  Hope it gets easier from here on all of us (: Loolyboo xxx
Posts.Title: Herceptin Injection

Posts.Content: Hi Finished chemo in July, rads in Aug & being her2 positive, I am being given herceptin once every 3wks.  I had my 9th injection 2wks ago and it has left me feeling like I've had flu this time for 12 days, aching all over & exhausted - my symptoms seem to be getting worse as the injections progress. Just wondering if anyone else has felt this way with herceptin?
Posts.Title: Herceptin Injection

Posts.Content: Hi Nikki  I know exactly how you are feeling and please trust me that I promise you things will get better once your treatment is in place. I was diagnosed with grade 3 breast cancer in Jan last year, happily married aged 39 with two boys aged 2 & 9 and I felt exactly how you have described feeling too, it came out of the blue, no family history and is truly terrifying. If I could have this time back, I really wish that I hadn't wasted so much time and energy being scared but I know that's easier said than done. After biopsy, I was also told that it was in several nodes and had to have CT & MRI scans too which were thankfully clear.   Following lumpectomy and removal of 11 lymph nodes it was found that tiny cells (micromets) were found in just 1 node & the others were clear. Fast forward to now ... following surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy, I am sat here on holiday on the beach in Florida with my husband watching my son's playing in the ocean, oh and I even thave a cute hair style too! (: You will receive amazing support here, I couldn't have got through everything without it, be kind to yourself ...  ((BIG HUGS))
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - feel like I'm living a nightmare

Posts.Content: Signed, thank you for bringing it to our attention x
Posts.Title: petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

Posts.Content: Lizzy You actually made me belly laugh, especially your cats reaction to your wig lol!
Posts.Title: Me and my dead rat! Has anyone had wig problems?

Posts.Content: Hi Jen72 I had my last chemo on 6th July, planning session 18th & started radiotherapy yesterday 29th July.
Posts.Title: Times between chemo and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne That's great news! I had my last chemo on 6th July and I'm now on day 8 of rads with 12 to go. Here's hoping that this time next year all that we have been through will all seem a distant memory .. Take care.
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: Hi papa smurf I had the exact same operation 2wks ago (4th Feb) and also noticed that the pain increased throughout the 2nd week - my BC nurse explained that the muscles and nerves that were affected are slowly becoming less numb and gaining more feeling hence a little increase in pain. I had a drain attached for 7days and no evidence of swelling etc in my second week, doing my exercises daily too and all seems well :) Just awaiting a date for chemo to commence now, which should be in the next 10days or so. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Discomfort increasing

Posts.Content: Hi papa smurf I had the exact same operation 2wks ago (4th Feb) and also noticed that the pain increased throughout the 2nd week - my BC nurse explained that the muscles and nerves that were affected are slowly becoming less numb and gaining more feeling hence a little increase in pain. I had a drain attached for 7days and no evidence of swelling etc in my second week, doing my exercises daily too and all seems well :) Just awaiting a date for chemo to commence now, which should be in the next 10days or so. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Discomfort increasing

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah I had my lymph node clearance op plus lumpectomy just over 2wks ago on the 4th Feb and other than numbness under my armpit/shoulder blade & sunburn type pain to the skin, the pain was minimal and I took ibuprofen for the first 2days then found I didn't need to take anything. I had a drain for 7days which collected the lymphatic fluid and since removal, I have not had any build-up of fluid. I have been doing the exercises daily which have really helped, I can already reach with my arm straight above my head, really pleased with my progress :)  I started driving 12days post op - only to my local supermarket - I guess as my op was on my right side it made things easier to be able to use my 'good' arm to change gear. Take care.
Posts.Title: Axiallary clearance

Posts.Content: Love, love, love this post!  I'm 11days into my first Docetaxel after 3 FEC & my eyelashes and brows are still there - just wondering at what point I will lose them, being lulled into a false sense of security at t'mo eeeek!
Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne That's great news and another BIG step towards getting cured!  I'm off to my pre-chemo chat this afternoon, picc line being fit on Monday then 1st FEC chemo hopefully Tues. Keep in touch
Posts.Title: Good news on results

Posts.Content: Hi I had lumpectomy and lymph node clearance on 4th Feb, and I have been told today that chemo will not start until the 21st March which is over 6wks since my surgery from which I healed perfectly with no infections.  Chemo ward told me that they were very busy and short staffed! Has anyone else had to wait this long? Getting very anxious
Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: Hi G n J Thank you for your kind reply - yes, I am having a picc line and that's great news to hear you recommend them. My consultant said that chemo would start 4wks after surgery plus the NICE guidelines state 'chemotherapy should commence within 31 days of surgery' which is a worry .. Will give my oncologist a bell tomorrow for more reassurance. Thank you.
Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: Hi  Thank you all for your replies - all v thoughtful & reassuring.  However, it would seem I was destined to wait 6wks to commence chemo as I was diagnosed with shingles yesterday and am now on 5 tablets a day for 7 days!
Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Thank you all for such positive replies, certainly helped to put my mind at rest.
Posts.Title: Waiting forever!
